title: 112_s3218
content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 includes provisions for improved coordination of export promotion programs and facilitation of export opportunities for small businesses. It consolidates duplicative export promotion activities, clarifies roles of committee members, includes state agency representatives, and reports to Congress on activities. It also focuses on enhancing Export.gov as a single window for export information and developing a single window for export control compliance. TITLE I--IMPROVED COORDINATION OF EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS
Sec. 201-206: Various provisions for promoting exporting and small business export opportunities, including consolidation of duplicative activities, export control education, and inter-agency task force on export financing. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to improve coordination of export promotion programs by identifying opportunities for consolidation, coordinating electronic databases, and providing detailed listings of trade missions and fairs. The Secretary of Commerce is required to make information on trade missions available. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the Secretary of Commerce to provide information on Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities on the website Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles and objectives of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC, including the need for measuring and reporting on goals. Congress is also included in the oversight of export promotion and financing activities. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles and objectives of TPCC members, including recommendations from the Comptroller General and changing the reference to the United States Travel Association. SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress regarding the activities of the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require reports to Congress by the TPCC chairperson and the Inspector General of the Department of Commerce on strategic plans, implementation of export promotion activities, and interagency working groups on energy. Reports are due by March 30 of each year. The TPCC chairperson and the Inspector General of the Department of Commerce must report annually by March 30 on the successful implementation of duties and strategic plans. The Inspector General should consult with other Federal departments' inspectors general. Appropriate congressional committees include the Committee on Appropriations, Commerce, Science, and Transportation, Finance, Foreign Relations, and Small Business. The TPCC chairperson and the Inspector General of the Department of Commerce must report annually on the successful implementation of duties and strategic plans to appropriate congressional committees. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporters. The report should also propose making Export.gov a single platform for submitting all required information for exporting articles from the United States. The entities involved in this consultation include small business exporters and relevant government agencies. The curr_chunk discusses responsibilities related to export promotion, district export councils, and trade associations. The curr_chunk discusses the requirement for a report on developing a single website for export control compliance information. It specifies the timeline for submission and defines the appropriate congressional committees. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.
    Definitions for terms like "Administration," "Administrator," "region of the Administration," and "small business concern" are provided.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING.
    Amendment to the Small Business Act to include promoting exporting as a business development opportunity for small businesses.

SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers. At least one event will be held in each region annually, and events may be coordinated with outreach events. The program authority will end on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to review and improve Federal export finance programs. SEC. 206 ensures the availability of State resource guides on export.gov. SEC. 206 mandates the Secretary of Commerce to provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources by State.
